item.title: Covid-19: Mystery UK person with Brazil variant found
item.description: Health officials have also traced the contacts of the person, it is understood.

item.title: English travellers face fines and losing flights without new permit
item.description: Anyone travelling overseas from England from Monday will have to prove they are allowed to travel.

item.title: Treorchy: 'Number of casualties' involved in serious incident
item.description: The scene remains sealed off as South Wales Police continue investigations at Ynyswen, Rhondda.

item.title: Gordon Elliott: Irish trainer banned for 12 months for dead horse photo
item.description: Leading Irish trainer Gordon Elliott banned for 12 months, with the last six months suspended, after being found guilty of bringing the sport into disrepute.

item.title: Oprah interview: Meghan says it is 'liberating' to be able to speak
item.description: Being a royal was "different than I think what people imagine it to be", says the Duchess of Sussex.

item.title: Covid-19: Brazil variant case traced, and nurses prepare possible strike
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday evening.

item.title: NHS pay: Hancock defends 1% pay rise after union strike threats
item.description: The health secretary said the proposal was "what we think is affordable" after the Covid pandemic.

item.title: Mail on Sunday must publish front page statement of Meghan copyright win
item.description: A judge orders the Mail on Sunday to publish a statement about the Duchess of Sussex copyright victory.

item.title: Operation Midland: Met Police to face new inquiry
item.description: Merseyside police to ask why Scotland Yard did not refer false accusers for criminal investigation.

item.title: Prince Philip transfers back to King Edward VII's Hospital
item.description: Prince Philip, 99, is recuperating after a heart procedure on a pre-existing condition.

item.title: Sarah Everard: Police 'increasingly concerned' for Brixton woman
item.description: Sarah Everard has not been seen or heard from since Wednesday evening, her best friend says.

item.title: Parents not giving Covid test consent, warn heads
item.description: Heads say parents are not giving consent for Covid tests for children, ahead of going back to school.

item.title: World's oldest known wild bird has another chick at age of 70
item.description: Wisdom is believed to have had more than 30 chicks in her life so far, and several partners.

item.title: Sinkhole 'swallowed' Cumbrian farmer on quad bike
item.description: The ground "fell away" as the man rode across his field, leaving him trapped 60ft below the surface.

item.title: Northern Pacific seastar: The sea intruder causing havoc in Tasmania
item.description: Locals hope removing an introduced starfish can help save an iconic Australian species.

item.title: Our Lives: Will my hometown survive this lockdown?
item.description: An ongoing Covid-19 study has shown how the North of England was hit harder than the rest of the country.

item.title: Covid 19: 'His mental health has suffered all along'
item.description: Michael, who has dementia, hasn't been able to properly see his family for a year, due to Covid-19 restrictions in his nursing home.

item.title: Oppo's expanding phone can grow and shrink on demand
item.description: The concept phone has a flexible display that rolls up inside the device.

item.title: Celebrating the world's largest female afro
item.description: Simone Williams sees her hair, which measures nearly 1.5m in circumference, as a symbol of pride.

item.title: Coronavirus: Hairdressers reopen in the Netherlands
item.description: Hairdressers in the Netherlands have reopened after being shut since December.

item.title: International Women's Day: Illustrating the Covid-19 pandemic
item.description: These three artists turn complex research into easy to digest information to help fight coronavirus.

item.title: Why is Harry and Meghan's TV interview so controversial?
item.description: Harry and Meghan have given Oprah Winfrey an exclusive interview, which will be shown in the UK on Monday.

item.title: NHS pay rise: How much will staff be paid?
item.description: The government has recommended a 1% pay increase, but how is the final decision reached?

item.title: What is going on with government Covid contracts?
item.description: What was Matt Hancock criticised for and how does government procurement work?

item.title: Budget 2021: Four things missing from Rishi Sunak
item.description: Where was the help for the environment, social care, renters, and to cover the future costs of Covid?

item.title: Covid: Fresh air 'key to safer classrooms'
item.description: Knowing which windows to open and having shorter lessons could help when children return to school.

item.title: Plymouth model: 'I felt like I needed to cut my own hair off'
item.description: Model Jarrakeh Cherno Jarra cut his afro as a child to avoid the "hassle" of people touching it.

item.title: The Father: Why Olivia Colman's new film will leave you disorientated
item.description: The Father puts you in the confused head of a dementia sufferer, played by Sir Anthony Hopkins.

item.title: Nalleli Cobo: How a nine-year-old fought an oil company and won
item.description: Nalleli Cobo started suffering from asthma, nosebleeds and headaches.

item.title: When is the census and what is it for?
item.description: The once-a-decade survey gives a snapshot of UK life and helps find out what services are needed.

item.title: Data experts are becoming football's best signings
item.description: A growing number of clubs big and small are using more technology to help performances on the pitch.

item.title: Towns Fund: How were the winners chosen?
item.description: There has been controversy about the 45 towns sharing just over £1bn from the Towns Fund.

item.title: Team Sturgeon breathes a sigh of relief
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon's team believes no real punches were landed in eight hours of questioning by MSPs.

item.title: Why are QAnon believers obsessed with 4 March?
item.description: Believers are using an old, irrelevant law to herald the supposed return to power of Donald Trump.

item.title: Accidental handball rule changed by law makers
item.description: Accidental handball leading to a goal-scoring chance or goal for a team-mate will no longer be penalised say football's law makers.

item.title: Pant's dazzling ton takes Test away from England
item.description: Rishabh Pant's dazzling century ensures India repel a Ben Stokes-led England fightback on a compelling second day of the final Test in Ahmedabad.

item.title: Newcastle boss Bruce will do 'utmost' to find leak over training ground row
item.description: Newcastle boss Steve Bruce says he will do his "utmost" to find out who leaked a training ground row with Matt Ritchie to the media.

item.title: Williams launch disrupted as hackers breach augmented reality app
item.description: Williams are forced to abandon an augmented reality launch of their new Formula 1 car when the app they had designed was hacked.

item.title: Scotland 'intent' on hosting Euro 2020 matches, says First Minister Sturgeon
item.description: Scotland is still "absolutely intent" on hosting matches at Euro 2020 this summer, says first minister Nicola Sturgeon.

item.title: Postcode look-up: How many vaccinated where you live?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 20 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday in the UK or travel abroad?
item.description: The government has unveiled its plans for unlocking UK restrictions, including holiday travel.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As schools remain closed to most pupils, the BBC is offering a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Covid variant: What happens when coronavirus mutates?
item.description: New Covid-19 variants keep appearing – and their mutations are very different to the comic book kind.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.
